title:
ES-FUZZ: Improving the Coverage of Firmware Fuzzing with Stateful and
  Adaptable MMIO Models

sections.text:
## A B STRACT

Gray-box fuzzing is widely used for testing embedded systems (ESes). State-of-the-art (SOTA) gray-box fuzzers test ES firmware in fully emulated environments without real peripherals. They emulate missing peripherals to achieve decent code coverage. Some fuzzers infer the memory-mapped I/O (MMIO) behavior of firmware peripherals from the firmware binary. We find that these fuzzers emulate the inferred MMIO behavior using stateless and non-adaptive MMIO models, which perform poorly in handling ES firmware's MMIO reads to collectively retrieve a data chunk. This leaves ample room for improving the code coverage of these fuzzers.

We propose ES-Fuzz to improve the code coverage of each such fuzzer using stateful MMIO models that adapt to overcome the fuzzer's coverage bottlenecks. ES-Fuzz runs concurrently with a given fuzzer and starts a new run whenever the fuzzer's coverage stagnates. In each run, ES-Fuzz leverages a high-coverage test case to generate new stateful MMIO models that boost the coverage further. We have implemented ES-Fuzz upon Fuzzware and evaluated it with 24 popular ES firmware. ES-Fuzz is shown to enhance Fuzzware's coverage by up to $54 \%$ in 11 of them and trigger additional bugs in 5 of them without hurting the coverage in the remainder. ES-Fuzz's MMIO models are shown to describe a wide range of MMIO-retrieved data chunks and the firmware's usage of the same data chunk in various contexts.

## CCS CONCEPTS

- Security and privacy $\rightarrow$ Software and application security.

## KEYWORDS

Fuzzing, Firmware, MMIO, Taint Analysis, Symbolic Execution ACM Reference Format:
Wei-Lun Huang and Kang G. Shin. 2025. ES-FUZZ: Improving the Code Coverage of Firmware Fuzzing with Stateful and Adaptable MMIO Models. In Proceedings of ACM CCS'25 (Anonymous Submission to ACM CCS 2025). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 15 pages. https://doi.org/10.1145/nnnnnnn. nnnnnnn

## 1 INTRODUCTION Embedded systems (ESes) have drawn significant attention from the security community since they are ubiquitous, collect sensitive data, and help users make critical decisions. However, it remains challenging to detect ES vulnerabilities on a large scale, for ESes run on diverse hardware platforms and serve various purposes. Fuzzing is widely used to meet this challenge. A fuzzer can test ES [^0]Kang G. Shin
University of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA
kgshin@umich.edu firmware without specific microcontrollers (MCUs) or peripherals by running the firmware in a fully emulated environment. This, known as rehosting-based firmware fuzzing [5-7, 10-13, 16, 17, 20, $22,23,27,28]$, has been a popular option for testing ESes. A fuzzer detects crashes and hangs in ES firmware with randomly generated inputs. The performance of a firmware fuzzer is usually assessed with code coverage-the amount of code in the fuzzed firmware reached by fuzzer-generated inputs. A firmware fuzzer's code coverage is dominated by its policy for handling firmware interactions with peripherals. In rehosting-based firmware fuzzing, the fuzzed firmware cannot access real peripherals, and hence the fuzzer must emulate the firmware's intended peripherals to achieve high code coverage. State-of-the-art (SOTA) firmware fuzzers meet this requirement by emulating the memory-mapped I/O (MMIO) behavior of peripherals $[5,7,10,11,13,16,17,22,23,27,28]$. Many of these fuzzers emulate peripheral behavior with MMIO models. First, they infer the models from real-world firmware executions [16], dynamic symbolic executions (DSEs) [17, 22, 27], code patterns [13], or peripheral specifications [28]. Then, when such a fuzzer executes an MMIO read in the firmware under test, the read follows an appropriate model to retrieve a data value expected by the firmware. Existing MMIO models enable the fuzzer to handle the firmware's MMIO reads that control a peripheral, get a peripheral's status, or retrieve simple data. The fuzzer can thus progress beyond the firmware's (control/status-intensive) startup code and reach the firmware's (data-intensive) application code. The fuzzer may navigate further through the bare bones of the application code but is unlikely to cover more code. The above "coverage bottleneck" arises because existing MMIO models are stateless, fixed, and thus poor at describing MMIO reads in ES firmware that collectively retrieve a data chunk. A stateless model does not distinguish multiple reads from the same MMIO register. This limits the model's ability to represent a data chunk's syntax when different bytes of the data chunk follow different syntactic rules. A fixed model does not accept updates after being assigned to MMIO reads in the firmware under test. This limits the model's ability to represent a data chunk's semantics when the firmware processes the data chunk based on its current context. We will elaborate on the importance of stateful and adaptable MMIO models for firmware fuzz-testing with a code example (Sec. 3.2). We propose ES-Fuzz to improve the code coverage of firmware fuzz-testing with stateful and adaptable MMIO models. It runs concurrently with a given firmware fuzzer and starts a new run whenever the fuzzer's coverage stagnates. In each run, ES-Fuzz considers a high-coverage test case and generates stateful MMIO models that will likely boost the fuzzer's coverage. The considered test case is in the form of a detailed execution trace generated by an [^0]: Anonymous Submission to ACM CCS 2025, October 13 - October 17, 2025, Taipei, Taiwan 2025. ACM ISBN 978-1-4503-XXXX-X/25/10 https://doi.org/10.1145/nnnnnnn.nnnnnnn ![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg) Figure 1: ES-Fuzz and the given firmware fuzzer work together to improve fuzz-testing coverage. instrumented copy of the fuzzing harness (Sec. 4.1). The generated models will be used immediately by the fuzzer (Sec. 4.4). ES-Fuzz's trace-guided model generation (Sec. 4.2 and 4.3) addresses two key challenges in building stateful and adaptable MMIO models for firmware fuzz-testing. First, a stateful model must consider the dependency between individual reads from the same MMIO register. It should consider a minimal number of MMIO reads at a time-just enough to retrieve a complete data chunkto enable efficient model generation. To meet this requirement, ES-Fuzz groups MMIO reads in each detailed execution trace by the time the firmware used their retrieved data in the recorded execution. Each group is then presumed to have retrieved a complete data chunk. Second, a group of MMIO reads, when in different firmware contexts, should be described by different stateful models if the dependency between the reads is context-sensitive. ES-Fuzz favors efficient model generation, while firmware fuzzers favor simple models. Thus, ES-Fuzz neither enumerates all the contexts nor generates all the models in one run. It leverages the execution trace obtained in each run to build only the models that help the fuzzer overcome the current coverage bottleneck. We have implemented ES-Fuzz with Fuzzware [22] as the given firmware fuzzer, for it represents the SOTA in MMIO modeling for firmware fuzz-testing. Fig. 1 shows the interactions between ES-Fuzz and Fuzzware. In Sec. 7 we will discuss recent (1) firmware fuzzers that are orthogonal/complementary to MMIO modeling and (2) stateful fuzzers for testing programs beyond ES firmware. We have tested ES firmware commonly used in prior works with both ES-Fuzz and vanilla Fuzzware. ES-Fuzz is shown to improve Fuzzware's coverage by up to $54 \%$ and discover additional firmware vulnerabilities. The MMIO models generated by ES-Fuzz describe the firmware expectations of various MMIO-retrieved data chunks in different contexts of data usage. By evaluating our DSE heuristics for mitigating path explosions, we have shown that a vanilla DSE [26] cannot build most of ES-Fuzz's MMIO models with reasonable CPU and memory usage.

## 2 BACKGROUND
### 2.1 Firmware-Peripheral Interactions

ES firmware constantly interacts with peripherals and adjusts its control flow to the latest data received from peripherals during execution. Therefore, a test case in firmware fuzz-testing (i.e., a firmware input) refers to the collection of firmware-peripheral interactions in a firmware execution. These interactions primarily
occur in the forms of memory-mapped I/O (MMIO), interrupts (IRQs), and direct memory access (DMA).
MMIO. ES firmware reserves a region in the memory for MMIO, where each memory location is called an MMIO register. Each peripheral maps part of its registers and memory to a pre-assigned set of MMIO registers. The firmware can then interact with a peripheral by accessing the peripheral's MMIO registers.

There are three common types of MMIO registers [13]:

- Control Register (CR): by writing data to a peripheral's CR, ES firmware can control the peripheral's behavior.
- Status Register (SR): by updating its SR data, a peripheral can report its current status to ES firmware, which then reads the data and adjusts its control flow.
- Data Register (DR): a sensor peripheral can place the latest sensor reading in its DR for ES firmware to read; ES firmware can send a complex command to an actuator peripheral by writing command bytes sequentially to its DR. As a peripheral, a serial communication interface may have DRs that operate in both directions.
A CR/SR data is usually single-bit wide and self-contained, while a DR data may be multi-byte wide and dependent on previous DR data. Thus, MMIO reads from DRs are generally harder to emulate in firmware rehosting than those from CRs and SRs. Some MMIO registers contain bit fields of different functions (e.g., control bits and status bits [13]).

A research topic in rehosting-based firmware fuzzing is how to classify MMIO registers accessed by the fuzzed firmware. A baseline approach requires the CMSIS-SVD file [8, 16] of the intended MCU. SOTA fuzzers [13, 22, 27] adopt alternative approaches to accurately identify DRs. A read from an identified DR will retrieve arbitrary data during fuzzing, for the read is hard to emulate and the DR is assumed to be under adversarial control when the firmware is under attack.
IRQ. A peripheral may interact with ES firmware asynchronously by sending IRQs. The firmware maintains an interrupt vector table (IVT) that maps each interrupt ID to a function address. The function is an interrupt service routine (ISR) that handles all the incoming IRQs with this specific ID. Upon receiving an IRQ, the firmware extracts the interrupt ID, consults the IVT, and context-switches to the appropriate ISR. If the firmware reads a DR in an IRQ context, it tends to use the retrieved data outside the context [27]. In this paper, we will model MMIO reads that occur in IRQ contexts but not design new policies for IRQ modeling [12, 16, 28].

DMA. DMA enables a peripheral to access the memory of ES firmware without processor intervention. To transfer data via DMA, ES firmware first configures the DMA controller on its MCU with the data's source (e.g., a peripheral's DR), destination (e.g., a global uint8 array), size, etc. Then, when the data are ready for transfer, the DMA controller moves them from the source to the destination independently of MCU cores. Note that DMA modeling [20, 28] is not in the scope of this paper.

### 2.2 American Fuzzy Lop (AFL)

AFL is a coverage-guided fuzzer widely used for testing generalpurpose software. The software under test can be fuzzed by multiple AFL fuzzers concurrently for fast coverage growth. Each fuzzer in this setting uses a different policy for mutating and scheduling test cases, while a main fuzzer coordinates all the fuzzers. If AFL cannot run the software in the host environment, it emulates the software with QEMU [3]. AFL users may write a fuzzing harness to adjust the emulation setup and define how the software interprets a test case. A rehosting-based firmware fuzzer is typically built upon AFL, with a customized harness that tackles the differences between ES firmware and general-purpose software.

Google archived the original AFL codebase [15], while AFL++ [14], a fork maintained by the open-source community, still accepts feature requests and code updates. Some fuzzing options are only available in AFL++. For example, AFL++ can use Unicorn [21] as the emulator to fuzz a firmware binary. This option requires no code instrumentation, offers greater flexibility in emulation setup than QEMU, and has been adopted by recent firmware fuzzers.

### 2.3 Dynamic Symbolic Execution (DSE)

Symbolic execution is a program-analysis technique that assigns symbols rather than concrete values to program inputs and executes the program along all possible paths. Each executed instruction expresses its result in terms of the input symbols, and then each path leads to a path constraint that is the logical conjunction of all branch conditions along the path. An SMT solver (e.g., Z3 [9]) can check the satisfiability of a path constraint and, if possible, find a satisfying assignment. The path constraint will be satisfied if the input symbols are assigned the concrete values from a satisfying assignment. An unsatisfiable path constraint indicates that the program never takes the path when running with concrete inputs. The solver can also examine the conjunction of a path constraint and additional constraints that signal an event of interest. In this case, each satisfying assignment will be a program input that triggers the event when the program takes the path.

Applying symbolic execution to the entire program is generally infeasible as the number of a program's execution paths grows exponentially with the program size. We can offset the explosion of the number of paths with dynamic symbolic execution: run most of a program's code with concrete inputs, and only the code of interest with symbolic inputs. Prior work on MMIO modeling for firmware fuzzing only symbolically executes the code surrounding an MMIO read in ES firmware [5, 17, 22, 27, 28]. It further prunes or prioritizes symbolic firmware states with heuristics since a vanilla DSE is not enough to avoid path explosions [26]. We will elaborate
on this issue in Sec. 5.5 and Appendix B. We use ang $r$ [25] as the DSE engine to implement ES-Fuzz.

## 3 OVERVIEW OF ES-FUZZ

This section provides an overview of ES-Fuzz. Sec. 3.1 introduces the stateful and adaptable MMIO models generated by ES-Fuzz. Sec. 3.2 motivates the use of these MMIO models in rehosting-based firmware fuzzing through a real-world example. Sec. 3.3 describes the cooperation between ES-Fuzz and a given firmware fuzzer to generate and use these MMIO models during fuzzing.

### 3.1 Stateful and Adaptable MMIO Models

In rehosting-based firmware fuzzing, ES firmware interacts with emulated peripherals according to a fuzzer-generated schedule for each execution. The fuzzer usually generates a schedule-a firmware input-in two steps. First, it runs a coverage-guided fuzzing engine (e.g., AFL) to generate a random byte string. Then, it runs a harness equipped with the firmware's peripheral models (e.g., MMIO models) to translate the byte string into a schedule. Some firmware fuzzers, like Hoedur [23] and MultiFuzz [7], aim to improve the first step. Others, like Fuzzware [22] and ES-Fuzz, aim to improve the second. A firmware fuzzer mainly adopts peripheral models that describe the MMIO behavior of firmware peripherals [13, 16, 17, 22, 27, 28]. ES firmware performs each MMIO access as a memory access, so the only uncertainty to a firmware fuzzer in handling an MMIO access is the data retrieved by an MMIO read.

```

# one random byte consumed per modeled MMIO read
pc_000813cc_mmin_400e0810:
    access_size: 0x4
    mask: 0xff
    left_shift: 0x0
    size: 0x1 # byte entropy
```

Listing 1: Fuzzware's MMIO model

```

# one random byte consumed per model (re)selection
1sr_00080710_mmin_400e0810:
    0: undef # fall back on Fuzzware's model
    1: [0x73,0x74,0x65,0x65,0x72,0x2c,0x0a] # 'steer,\n'
    2: [0x6d,0x6f,0x74,0x6f,0x72,0x2c,0x0a] # 'motor,\n'
    ... # 'motor,6\n' 'steer,585\n', 'motor,678\n'
    14: [0x6d,0x6f,0x74,0x6f,0x72,0x2c,0x36,0x0a]
    15: [0x73,0x74,0x65,0x65,0x72,0x2c,0x35,0x38,0x35,0x0a]
    16: [0x6d,0x6f,0x74,0x6f,0x72,0x2c,0x36,0x37,0x38,0x0a]
```

Listing 2: ES-Fuzz's MMIO model
The fuzzer resolves this uncertainty by assigning an appropriate MMIO model to each MMIO read. The model will map the read to a data value expected by the firmware binary, peripheral specifications, etc. Then, the read will retrieve the data value upon its execution by the fuzzer. The above mapping process consumes fuzzer-generated random bytes if the model is multivalued. Note that a multivalued model is not necessarily stateful, and vice versa. Take the MMIO models in Listings 1 and 2 as examples. Fuzzware and ES-Fuzz generate these models when testing the Steering Control firmware from P2IM [13]. Both models describe the firmware's reads from the MMIO register at 0x400e0818. Fuzzware's model indicates in its name the common instruction address of these reads, while ES-Fuzz's indicates the common type of their IRQ contexts. Fuzzware's model is multivalued but stateless. It consumes one

random byte $0 \mathrm{x} X Y$ to map each modeled read to the data value $0 \times 000000 X Y$. ES-Fuzz's model is multivalued and stateful, containing 16 single-valued stateful models. It consumes one random byte $Z$ upon each model (re)selection, computes $z=Z \bmod 17$, and maps subsequent modeled reads one-on-one to data values in the 2 -th single-valued model. ES-Fuzz's model is also adaptable. Its later single-valued models are generated in its later runs and represent richer syntax/semantics of the modeled MMIO data than its earlier single-valued models.

### 3.3 System Workflow

We propose ES-Fuzz to generate the MMIO models introduced in Sec. 3.1 and address the limitation of existing firmware fuzzers illustrated in Sec. 3.2. Fig. 1 depicts ES-Fuzz's workflow. ES-Fuzz runs concurrently with a given rehosting-based firmware fuzzer. The fuzzer, in its original form, tests ES firmware with stateless and fixed MMIO models. ES-Fuzz starts a new run whenever the fuzzer has not covered more basic blocks ( BBs ) in the firmware or deployed more MMIO models for a while. In each run, ES-Fuzz leverages a high-coverage test case to build new stateful MMIO models that will direct the fuzzer to new firmware BBs.

Let us elaborate on ES-Fuzz's inputs in each run. ES-Fuzz considers a test case that covers the most (at least one) of the firmware BBs not covered by any test cases it considered before. It will suspend a run if no such test case exists. ES-Fuzz expects the given firmware fuzzer to provide all the test cases, MMIO models in use, and a fuzzing log that lists the firmware BBs covered thus far. It also expects the fuzzer to provide a list of firmware BBs covered by each test case. Most rehosting-based firmware fuzzers generate such lists on demand for debugging and development purposes. ES-Fuzz will identify the test case to consider using these lists.

Once ES-Fuzz has built new MMIO models in a run, the fuzzer uses the models in subsequent fuzz-testing to overcome its current coverage bottleneck. The interactions between ES-Fuzz and the fuzzer thus improve the fuzz-testing coverage iteratively. So far, we have explained ES-Fuzz's workflow by treating each ES-Fuzz run as a black box. Next, we will cover the details of a single run.

## 4 SYSTEM DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION

This section describes our design and implementation of ES-Fuzz. It elaborates on ES-Fuzz's steps in each run as Sec. 3.3 has covered the interactions between ES-Fuzz and a given firmware fuzzer. In each run, ES-Fuzz performs three steps using the firmware binary and the fuzzer-generated data outlined in Fig. 1.

First, ES-Fuzz identifies the test case of interest and acquires a detailed execution trace of the firmware running with that test case. The trace comes from an instrumented copy of the given fuzzing harness. To get this copy, we manually instrument the harness once in a fuzzer-dependent but firmware-agnostic manner. Each detailed trace lists the BBs and MMIO accesses executed by the firmware in chronological order. It highlights MMIO reads that have retrieved part of a data chunk and records the firmware's usage of the data retrieved by these reads. Sec. 4.1 will explain how our instrumented harness generates a detailed execution trace.

Second, ES-Fuzz groups the highlighted MMIO reads in a trace based on when the firmware used their data in the recorded execution. It then presumes each group to have retrieved a complete data chunk and may match a group with constant strings in the

firmware binary. Sec. 4.2 will explain how we group the MMIO reads and match a group with firmware strings.

Lastly, ES-Fuzz runs DSE on each group of MMIO reads. It only executes the firmware code where the MMIO reads occur and where the retrieved data chunk is used. Each DSE begins with an appropriate snapshot of the firmware state taken by the instrumented harness. When the DSE runs the MMIO-read code, it follows the path recorded in the detailed execution trace. When the DSE runs the data-use code, it prioritizes and prunes symbolic firmware states with heuristics. Sec. 4.3 will explain how we enhance the DSE efficiency with a detailed execution trace and heuristics.

If the DSE running on a group of MMIO reads reaches some BBs not yet covered by the given firmware fuzzer, it will return the corresponding values of the MMIO data to ES-Fuzz upon termination. Then, ES-Fuzz builds new stateful MMIO models from these data values, and the fuzzer shortly adopts the models. We expect these models to fit the data chunk retrieved by the MMIO reads better than the fuzzer's native models. Sec. 4.4 will explain the conversion from the DSE-returned data values to our MMIO models. Sec. 4.5 will describe our implementation of ES-Fuzz.

### 4.1 The Instrumented Harness

ES-Fuzz diagnoses the coverage bottleneck of the given firmware fuzzer in each run using a test case as a lens. It uses the one that covers the most of the firmware BBs not covered by any previously used test cases. This test case is presumed to cover the most of the firmware's application code not yet analyzed by ES-Fuzz. ES-Fuzz will analyze the MMIO reads in such code that retrieve part of a data chunk, for we assume some of these reads to have created the bottleneck by retrieving undesired data values. To identify these reads, ES-Fuzz needs a detailed execution trace of the firmware running with the test case. We manually instrument a copy of the given fuzzing harness to generate this trace on demand. ES-Fuzz will stick with this instrumented harness across different runs and for testing different ES firmware until the user replaces the given firmware fuzzer.

```

# two visited BBs
BB 1fd7, ADDR 813cc, IRQ 80718-3
BB 5ea0, ADDR 824de, IRQ 0-0

# an executed MMIO read
BB 1fd7, PC 813cc, MMIO 400e0818, SIZE 4, VAL 00000073

# a tainted RAM read
BB 5ea0, PC 824e4, RAM 20071270, SIZE 4, VAL 65657473,
    SRC 1fd7 813cc 400e0818 80718-3, # MMIO data
    SRC 27ab 813cc 400e0818 80718-4, # MMIO data

# a tainted non-memory instruction
BB 5ea0, PC 82582,
    SRC 1fd7 813cc 400e0818 80718-3, # MMIO data
    SRC 27ab 813cc 400e0818 80718-4, # MMIO data
    SRC 84b17 74 84b13 0-0 # string byte
```

Listing 4: Some events in a detailed execution trace
While running with a test case, the harness logs the visited BBs, the executed MMIO accesses, and the results of a dynamic taint analysis chronologically in a detailed execution trace. Listing 4 is excerpted from such a trace when ES-Fuzz tests the Steering Control firmware used in Sec. 3. The trace records the IRQ context of each BB, which applies to every event in the BB. It timestamps
each event with the dynamic count of BBs and the program-counter (PC) value. It expresses each number in hexadecimal and each IRQ context in both the ISR address ( 0 for events not in an IRQ context) and the number of IRQs of this type that have occurred.

In the taint analysis, the harness taints data retrieved by the firmware's MMIO reads and tracks the firmware's usage of these data at the instruction level. ES-Fuzz will consider the timings of data usage in its next step for grouping MMIO reads that have collectively retrieved a complete data chunk. The harness does not taint MMIO data that are unlikely to form a data chunk according to the fuzzer-specific heuristics in Appendix A. It taints the firmware's CPU registers and memory locations whose current values are derived from the tainted MMIO data. When it exits an IRQ context or a function not in an IRQ context, it removes taints from the respective part of the call stack. The above taint propagation ignores branch instructions for efficiency.

The harness logs each taint sink and its relevant taint sources during the taint analysis, as shown in Listing 4. We define the taint sinks to be the executed instructions that use a tainted MMIO data (a taint source) outside the place of the MMIO read's occurrence. The read may have occurred in an IRQ context or in a function not in any IRQ contexts. This definition of taint sinks is inspired by the observation that if an MMIO read retrieves part of a data chunk, its data is usually consumed outside its context [27].

The harness also tracks the firmware's usage of constant strings while running with a test case. ES-Fuzz will use this information to speed up its DSE. To this end, the harness extends its taint analysis such that the taint sources now include bytes of the constant strings loaded from the firmware binary to the memory. This way, each trace from the harness will record the string bytes that the firmware uses together with the tainted MMIO data. Take the last line in Listing 4 as an example. It refers to the byte "I" (i.e., 0x74) at 0x84b13 in the string "steer" that ends at 0x84b17.

The harness provides snapshots of the firmware state upon ES-Fuzz's request such that ES-Fuzz's DSE will begin with appropriate firmware states. Each request has the name of a test case and a list of timestamps (dynamic BB counts and PC values). Upon receiving a request, the harness runs the firmware with the specified test case and, at each specified time, takes a snapshot of both CPU registers and the allocated memory.

### 4.2 Clustering of MMIO Reads

ES-Fuzz now has a detailed execution trace of the firmware under test running with the test case of interest. The trace records the sinks and their relevant sources in a taint analysis described in Sec. 4.1. ES-Fuzz regards each MMIO data among the recorded taint sources as part of a data chunk and each associated taint sink as a moment when the firmware used that data chunk. ES-Fuzz will group the MMIO reads behind these MMIO data such that each group is presumed to have retrieved a complete data chunk. It will also match a group with constant strings against which the data chunk was likely compared during the firmware execution.

Before grouping the MMIO reads, ES-Fuzz partitions them by their IRQ-context types and MMIO-register addresses. This ensures that MMIO reads in the same group will have occurred in the same type of IRQ contexts and at the same MMIO register. The DSE in

ES-Fuzz's next step can then use aggressive heuristics at the cost of modeling the relation between MMIO reads with different registers or context types.

We have observed that typical ES firmware only consumes the tainted MMIO data after they form a meaningful data chunk. So, ES-Fuzz groups the MMIO reads in each partition by the time the firmware used their MMIO data. The grouping works as follows.
(1) For each read in the partition, ES-Fuzz builds a chronological sequence of taint sinks in the trace whose taint sources include the data retrieved by the read.
(2) Each read $M$ is assigned a singleton set $\{M\}$ and a time interval during which the firmware used the retrieved data. The interval starts at the first taint sink in the sequence and ends at the last.
(3) ES-Fuzz merges two sets of MMIO reads and their intervals whenever the intervals overlap. This merging continues until all the remaining intervals are disjoint. Then, the remaining sets of MMIO reads are the final results.
Some taint sinks in the trace are memory instructions that copied the tainted MMIO data from one buffer to another before the data formed a complete data chunk. The above grouping process may thus ignore taint sinks that are memory instructions. Still, ES-Fuzz will use these taint sinks later to detect the mismatches between constant strings and groups of MMIO reads and to start its DSE with appropriate snapshots of the firmware state.

ES-Fuzz matches a group of MMIO reads with a constant string in the firmware under test if the trace indicates that the firmware once used their retrieved MMIO data together with the string bytes. The matching works as follows.
(1) ES-Fuzz identifies every null-terminated array of printable ASCII characters in the loadable segments of the firmware binary. It regards each such array as a constant string that may contain bogus leading characters.
(2) For each group of MMIO reads, ES-Fuzz examines the taintsink sequences built for them during the grouping. It starts with an empty set $C$. A pair $\langle M, c\rangle$ joins $C$ if the taint sources of an examined sink include both the data of the MMIO read $M$ and a character $c$ from an identified constant string.
(3) After examining all the taint-sink sequences, ES-Fuzz groups the pairs $\left\langle M^{*}, c^{*}\right\rangle$ in $C$ by the string each $c^{*}$ belongs.
(4) Each group $G$ of the pairs $\left\langle M^{*}, c^{*}\right\rangle$ matches a constant string -free of bogus leading characters-with the group of MMIO reads. The string starts with the $c^{*}$ in $G$ at the lowest memory address and is specifically matched with all the $M^{*}$ in $G$.
Step 4 matches a string with only a few of the grouped MMIO reads mentioned in Step 2 to ease the burden of ES-Fuzz's DSE. It also deletes bogus characters from each string identified in Step 1. The firmware unlikely used bogus string characters together with the data chunk retrieved by the grouped MMIO reads. It likely compared the data chunk against a constant string starting with the leading characters of both. Hence, Step 4 deletes the leading characters of each identified string up to the first one the firmware used together with the data chunk. In rare cases, the firmware concatenated rather than compared the data chunk and a matched constant string. It then likely read or wrote part of the both sides with a single instruction. ES-Fuzz detects such an instruction and
corrects the mismatch by examining taint sinks in the trace that are memory instructions.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2: Clustering of the MMIO reads presumed to have collectively retrieved a complete data chunk

We illustrate ES-Fuzz's clustering of MMIO reads using a later part of the detailed execution trace shown in Listing 4. Fig. 2 visualizes how ES-Fuzz groups MMIO reads in the trace that have collectively retrieved a complete data chunk. Each point $(x, y)$ indicates that a taint sink in the $x$-th visited BB has data retrieved by the $y$-th executed MMIO access as a taint source. ES-Fuzz groups these points together until all the groups are disjoint along the X -axis (i.e., separated by the vertical dashed lines). The clustering ends with the point groups enclosed by the colored rectangles. The Y-axis projection of each point group is a group of MMIO reads matched with the strings "steer" and "motor".

### 4.3 DSE with Heuristics

ES-Fuzz has grouped MMIO reads in a detailed execution trace in Sec. 4.2 such that each group retrieved a complete data chunk in the recorded firmware execution. ES-Fuzz will now configure and run DSE on each group of MMIO reads to build new stateful MMIO models that describe the retrieved data chunk more accurately. The DSE will run the firmware code where the reads occurred and where the data chunk was used. It will attempt to reach the BBs not yet covered by the given firmware fuzzer. It is unlikely to reach any such BBs within a reasonable time along arbitrary execution paths, for the code-to-run typically spans multiple functions. So, ES-Fuzz speeds up the DSE with the detailed trace and our heuristics.
4.3.1 Symbolic Execution of the MMIO Reads. If ES firmware gets a data chunk through multiple MMIO reads, it tends to encode its expectations about the data chunk into its data-use code instead of its MMIO-read code. So, in principle, ES-Fuzz's DSE executes each group of MMIO reads along the path recorded in the detailed execution trace. However, in practice, these reads are executed differently based on their occurrence contexts.

If the MMIO reads in a group do not occur in IRQ contexts, they usually occur near the firmware code that uses their retrieved data chunk. In such a case, ES-Fuzz's DSE runs the MMIO-read and datause codes together. It begins with a snapshot of the firmware state at the occurrence of the first read in the group. It adapts the snapshot

Table 1: Heuristics for prioritizing and pruning symbolic firmware states in ES-Fuzz’s DSE

![table_0](table_0)

such that an MMIO read executed later will retrieve symbolic data if the read belongs to the group. The DSE will thereafter be ready to run the data-use code (together with the MMIO-read code).

If the MMIO reads in a group occur in IRQ contexts, they usually occur independently of, and sometimes far from, the firmware code that uses their retrieved data chunk. In such a case, ES-Fuzz’s DSE runs the MMIO-read and data-use codes separately. It runs the MMIO-read code by identifying ISRs that contain the grouped MMIO reads and running these ISRs as many times and in the same order as recorded in the detailed execution trace. Each ISR follows the path recorded in the trace. Each executed MMIO read retrieves symbolic data if it belongs to the group; otherwise, it retrieves the data value recorded in the trace.

Before running the identified ISRs, the above DSE locates the first taint sink in the trace whose taint sources include the data retrieved by some MMIO reads in the group. This taint sink, which should be a RAM read, marks the moment $t$ the firmware started to use the data chunk retrieved by the grouped MMIO reads. The instrumented harness in Sec. 4.1 then provides the DSE with the firmware-state snapshots $S_{d}$ at $t$ and $S_{m}$ at each entry to the identified ISRs that occurred before $t$. The DSE starts to run these ISRs with their respective $S_{m}$. Upon exiting each such ISR, the DSE transfers the remaining symbolic memory contents (outside the ISR’s part of the call stack) to $S_{d}$. After running all these ISRs, the DSE will start to run the data-use code with $S_{d}$. It will attempt to run the rest of the identified ISRs (i.e., those occurring after $t$ ) with every symbolic firmware state it reaches. It will also run ISRs in the trace that occurred between the grouped MMIO reads. Each attempt stops when an ISR overwrites unused MMIO data or deviates from the path recorded in the trace.

sections.text:
# 4.3.2 Symbolic Execution of the Data Usage. The DSE running on 

each group of MMIO reads now has a modified snapshot of the firmware state, as described in Sec. 4.3.1. The DSE will use this snapshot as the initial state to run the firmware code that uses the data chunk retrieved by the grouped MMIO reads. In this process, the DSE should not spend much effort on other MMIO reads as they are not interesting to ES-Fuzz. To this end, two pointers in the detailed execution trace are associated with each symbolic firmware state: a BB pointer and an MMIO pointer to a BB and an MMIO access in the trace. When the DSE executes an MMIO read in a state, the state’s BB and MMIO pointers map this MMIO read to one in the trace. The state’s read will retrieve a symbol if the trace’s
read is among the grouped ones. Otherwise, the state’s read will retrieve the data value of the trace’s read.

The DSE sets up the BB and MMIO pointers of its initial state as follows. If the group of MMIO reads occurred in IRQ contexts, the BB pointer points to where the firmware started to use the retrieved data chunk. Then, the MMIO pointer points to the next MMIO access to occur. Otherwise, the MMIO pointer points to the first read in the group, and the BB pointer points to its BB. The DSE maintains the two pointers of each state as follows. Each successor of a state upon a branch is mapped to a BB in the trace with the same BB address and IRQ context. It is mapped to the first such BB after the location pointed to by the state’s BB pointer. Then, its BB pointer points to that BB ( $\infty$ if there is no such BB). Each MMIO access in a state, when executed by the DSE, is mapped to one in the trace with the same MMIO register, PC value, and IRQ context. It is mapped to the first such MMIO access after the location pointed to by the state’s MMIO pointer (and BB pointer if not $\infty$ ). Then, the state’s MMIO pointer is updated to that MMIO access.

The DSE will likely suffer path/state explosions before reaching any wanted BBs if it treats all states equally. To prevent this, the DSE maintains a priority queue of states and follows the heuristics in Table 1. At first, the queue only contains the initial state. The DSE repeatedly dequeues a state, runs with it until it produces successors upon a branch, and enqueues these successors. Let us elaborate on Table 1. The DSE checks C2 for each state using the all-pair shortest paths in a static control-flow graph (CFG) of the firmware under test. It targets the paths from the state’s BB to the wanted BBs in the same function or the callees. A state’s history of register contents in C5 records the register values in each ancestor of the state and resets when an MMIO read occurs. If the DSE exits an IRQ context or a function outside IRQ contexts while running with a state, it zeros the respective part of the state’s call stack. This enables the DSE to check C6 for each state accurately.

The DSE running on a group of MMIO reads terminates when it times out, its queue becomes empty, or $P$ consecutive states from its queue do not cover more wanted BBs. $P$ is the number of states the DSE took from its queue before reaching any wanted BBs ( $\infty$ if it has reached none). Whenever the DSE reaches a new wanted BB, an SMT solver finds concrete values for the data of the grouped MMIO reads to satisfy the path constraint. ES-Fuzz will build a stateful model for these reads from the data values.

### 4.3.3 Scheduling DSE for the MMIO-Read Groups. ES-Fuzz labels

each group of MMIO reads with their common MMIO register and

type of IRQ contexts. Then, it runs DSE in parallel on the groups with different labels. Among the groups with identical labels, the DSE prioritizes those matched with more firmware strings and then those whose retrieved data chunk was used earlier. If the DSE reaches a wanted BB while running on a group, it will skip the remaining groups with identical labels.

If running on a group of MMIO reads matched with firmware strings, the DSE can speed up by forcing some of these reads to retrieve specific characters of a matched string. The DSE tests each assignment of string characters to MMIO reads with a copy of the initial state in Sec. 4.3.2. To exhaust possible assignments, it assigns the start of each matched string to each $M^{*}$ in Step 4 of the matching in Sec. 4.2. Then, the DSE runs with the resulting initial-state copies in parallel for different strings. The DSE per string prioritizes the copy that assigns the string start to an earliest $M^{*}$ and terminates when a copy yields a wanted BB.

### 4.4 Model Generation and Deployment

We discuss the case where ES-Fuzz's DSE reaches a wanted BB when running on a group of MMIO reads with the label $(I, R) . I$ and $R$ denote the type of IRQ contexts and MMIO register where these reads occurred. The DSE will return the concrete data values of these reads. ES-Fuzz will build a stateful model from the returned data values for MMIO reads with the label $(I, R)$ in the firmware under test.

This model should enable the given firmware fuzzer to cover the BB reached by the DSE. To this end, the model considers both the current group of MMIO reads and any previous groups with identical labels in the detailed execution trace. It lists the data values of the previous and current groups from the trace and the DSE, respectively, in chronological order. A read in the current group gets an undefined data value if not constrained by the DSE.

The fuzzer will deploy this model in subsequent firmware testing alongside the previous models from ES-Fuzz for the same MMIO reads, as depicted in Fig. 1 and Listing 2. It will also deploy a dummy stateful model to fall back on its native models when favorable. The fuzzer will randomly select the stateful model to use before each firmware execution or when the previously-selected model is used up. Then, each modeled MMIO read in an execution will retrieve the next unused data value in the selected model. The read proceeds with the fuzzer's native models if the value is undefined. When using a stateful model from ES-Fuzz, the fuzzer randomly skips the singletons of MMIO reads therein for flexibility.

ES-Fuzz starts its next run when the fuzzer has not covered more firmware BBs or deployed more MMIO models for a while. Its DSE in each run adapts to the stateful MMIO models deployed so far. If some of them already describe the $i$-th group of MMIO reads with the label $(I, R)$ in a firmware execution, the DSE will skip running on the first $i-1$ groups with this label.

### 4.5 Implementation

We implement ES-Fuzz for the popular ARM Cortex-M architecture, using Fuzzware [22] (commit d047baf) as the given firmware fuzzer and angr [25] (9.2.61) as the DSE engine. The implementation in Python, C, and Bash consists of two parts: an instrumented copy of Fuzzware's harness and a program that builds stateful MMIO
models from a detailed execution trace. It takes $\sim 1100$ lines of code to build the first part, $\sim 2000$ lines to build the second, and $\sim 240$ lines to coordinate the two and Fuzzware. In the first part, we have also modified Fuzzware's harness. It will then accommodate ES-Fuzz's MMIO models and follow the same execution path as its instrumented copy when running with the same test case. To achieve the latter, Fuzzware's harness will count native BBs rather than translation blocks in the firmware under test for firing IRQs periodically during firmware execution.

Fuzzware and ES-Fuzz run concurrently on different cores (see Sec. 5 for their core counts). Fuzzware tests ES firmware nonstop and outputs a list of the covered BBs for each test case. ES-Fuzz will determine the test case of interest in each run with these BB lists, as described in Sec. 3.3. It starts a new run when (1) such a test case exists and (2) Fuzzware did not cover new BBs or deploy new MMIO models in the last $N=10$ minutes. We recommend $5 \leq$ $N \leq 30$ for 24-hour firmware fuzzing so ES-Fuzz will provide new MMIO models for Fuzzware frequently enough without disrupting Fuzzware's input mutations too often.

ES-Fuzz starts each run by running the instrumented harness with the test case of interest to generate a detailed execution trace described in Sec. 4.1. The harness identifies the IRQ context of each visited BB using Fuzzware's NVIC implementation. It detects function calls and returns by monitoring the ARM SP, LR, and PC register values. It logs the values of the ARM special registers for IRQ handling to the trace. ES-Fuzz's DSE will use this information to avoid running an ISR at a forbidden time.

The program for model generation loads each detailed execution trace as the partitions of events in the trace by their IRQ contexts. ES-Fuzz's DSE can then update a state's BB and MMIO pointers efficiently. The program loads each firmware binary as an angr project. ES-Fuzz can then obtain the all-pair shortest paths in the firmware's static CFG from angr. ES-Fuzz may match a group of MMIO reads in the loaded trace to a firmware string. The program in such a case will generate an MMIO model that solely describes this string for the same type of MMIO reads in the firmware. This is similar to Redqueen [2]. In the program, ES-Fuzz's DSE times out after an hour when running on each group of MMIO reads.

ES-Fuzz's DSE slows down when executing floating-point operations in the firmware under test that are implemented in integer and bit-vector arithmetics. Each such operation is a function in math. $h$ or aeabi. $h$ and follows the same I/O relation across different firmware. So, we build their Python equivalents that express their I/O relations in floating-point arithmetic. ES-Fuzz's DSE then speeds up by executing the equivalents instead of the original floating-point operations.

## 5 EVALUATION

We evaluate ES-Fuzz to address the following questions.
Q1. Does ES-Fuzz enable a given firmware fuzzer to cover more code and trigger more bugs in the firmware under test?
Q2. Does ES-Fuzz generate MMIO models that describe a data chunk retrieved by multiple MMIO reads? If so, do the models reflect different usage contexts of the data chunk?
Q3. Can ES-Fuzz generate its MMIO models using a vanilla DSE (i.e., without the heuristics introduced in Sec. 4.3)?

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3: ES-Fuzz's and Fuzzware's coverage in the firmware under test over 24 hours

To answer these questions, we applied vanilla Fuzzware and the ES-Fuzz implementation in Sec. 4.5 to 24 ES firmware widely used in prior work [7, 11, 13, 16, 22, 23, 27]. The two firmware fuzzers ran on a 64-core Intel Xeon E5-2683 v4 machine with 254GB RAM, fuzzed each firmware on four cores, and built their MMIO models concurrently on additional cores.

### 5.1 Improvement in Code Coverage

We tested each firmware with both fuzzers in three independent 24-hour trials and recorded the code coverage in Fig. 3 and Table 3. Fig. 3 plots the number of firmware BBs covered over time by each fuzzer in each trial. It focuses on the 11 firmware where ES-Fuzz boosted Fuzzware's coverage. The red and blue curves per firmware represent the median coverage of ES-Fuzz and Fuzzware, respectively, across trials at each sampled time. Each shaded area is then bounded by a fuzzer's minimum and maximum coverage across trials. Table 3 lists the numbers of BBs in each firmware, of those covered by each fuzzer in each trial (min/med/max), and of those covered in at least one trial (total). Fig. 3 shows that ES-Fuzz raised Fuzzware's coverage during a trial by up to 195\% (in RF Door Lock, after 8.7 hours). Table 3 shows that ES-Fuzz improved Fuzzware's total coverage across trials by up to 54\% (in ChibiOS RTC). We will elaborate on the way ES-Fuzz's MMIO models enhanced Fuzzware's coverage in Sec. 5.4.

Gateway and RF Door Lock are the only firmware in Fig. 3 in which ES-Fuzz did not always outperform Fuzzware in the final code coverage per trial in Table 3. As a result, their shaded areas in Fig. 3 overlap at the 24th hour. In the Gateway's case, ES-Fuzz covered multiple branches in the firmware's Firmata parser during the trials by modeling various Firmata messages. However, its DSE never ran long enough to model beyond three bytes of each Firmata message. Moreover, the parser is branch-heavy and takes a branch upon each incoming message byte. These gave Fuzzware's underlying fuzzing engine (i.e., AFL) a chance to catch up with ES-Fuzz's coverage by the end of a trial. In the RF Door Lock's case, ES-Fuzz covered most of the firmware routines by first modeling a magic word (i.e., "OK\n\n") that guards the entry to all these routines. This magic word is so short that AFL got it by the end of every trial via input mutations. Still, compared to AFL's input mutations, ES-Fuzz's MMIO models enabled Fuzzware to cover
noticeably more code in these two firmware (1) at the early stage of every trial and (2) across the trials.

We classify the firmware where ES-Fuzz did not improve Fuzzware's coverage into two cases. The six firmware at the bottom of Table 3 are the ones ES-Fuzz did not provide Fuzzware with any MMIO models. In such a case, ES-Fuzz and vanilla Fuzzware fuzzed firmware in the same way, so comparing their code coverage is not meaningful. Robot and Thermostat fell into this case as ES-Fuzz's DSE stalled upon some of their conditional instructions. Reflow Oven fell into this case as its MMIO-retrieved temperature reading bits were not among the taint sources of ES-Fuzz's taint analysis. The firmware converted each bit upon retrieval to a constant $0 / 1$ using a branch instruction. Our taint analysis ignored this instruction and thus lost track of the bit.

The seven firmware in the middle of Table 3 are the ones Fuzzware did not cover noticeably more code with ES-Fuzz's MMIO models. Fuzzware could always fall back on its native MMIO models during the trials using the dummy models introduced in Sec. 4.4. So, ES-Fuzz still covered roughly as much code in these firmware as vanilla Fuzzware ( $\leq 3.5 \%$ drop in the "total" in Table 3). We found that ES-Fuzz's models for 6LoWPAN Sender/Receiver, Heat Press, and PLC are false positives (see Sec. 5.4) but hardly hurt Fuzzware's coverage. In contrast, ES-Fuzz's models for CNC, XML Parser, and Zephyr SocketCAN hurt Fuzzware's coverage a bit but describe the firmware's data chunks more accurately than Fuzzware's models.

### 5.2 Newly Discovered Bugs

Fuzzware triggered additional bugs in five firmware under test when equipped with ES-Fuzz. Below, we describe these bugs and ES-Fuzz's advantage in triggering them. As some of them have been reported in the concurrent efforts [6, 7, 11], we are contacting the firmware developers about the not-yet-reported ones.

Console. An out-of-bounds (OOB) read occurs in dow when the firmware calls this function with a month value greater than 12. It calls dow when parsing the MMIO-retrieved user commands "rtc (settime, setalarm) YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:SS" to obtain the day of week. To trigger this bug, Fuzzware must feed "rtc settime" or "rtc setalarm" to the firmware. It met this requirement during the trials with ES-Fuzz's MMIO models that describe these two

command prefixes. Fuzzware did not assign its MMIO models to the command-retrieving MMIO reads.

Contiki-NG Shell. A null-pointer dereference occurs in strcmp when the firmware attempts to parse a missing argument in the MMIO-retrieved user command "rpl-set-root". The firmware assigns a null pointer to this argument but proceeds with parsing regardless. To trigger this bug, Fuzzware must feed "rpl-set-root" to the firmware without misspellings. It met this requirement during the trials with ES-Fuzz's MMIO model that describes this long command. In contrast, Fuzzware's native model for the commandretrieving MMIO reads simply extracts the lowest byte from each 4-byte MMIO data.

GPS Tracker. A null-pointer dereference will occur in strtok if the firmware cannot find "AT+GSN/r/r'n" in its stream of the received MMIO data during gsm_get_imei. In each attempt to load an AT-command response from the stream, the firmware assumes that the command and response are adjacent in the stream. So, it first calls strstr to locate the command and then strtok to extract the response. strstr will return a null pointer that breaks strtok if the command is not in the stream. To trigger this bug, Fuzzware must progress beyond gsm_set_pin and gsm_wait_modem_ready in gsm_config. It achieved this during the trials with ES-Fuzz's MMIO models that describe the necessary AT-command responses. Again, Fuzzware's native model for the response-retrieving MMIO reads simply extracts the lowest byte from each 4-byte MMIO data.
uTasker USB. An OOB write will occur in control_callback (via a call to uMemcpy) if the firmware extracts a large/invalid interface index from an MMIO-retrieved SET_LINE_COOING request. The firmware will copy the request contents into the USB CDC settings specified by that index, even when that index exceeds USB _CDC_COUNT. To trigger this bug, Fuzzware must feed the correct request header to the firmware. It met this requirement during the trials with ES-Fuzz's MMIO models that describe the USB OTG Full-Speed device data. Fuzzware did not assign its MMIO models to the request-retrieving MMIO reads.

CNC. CNC keeps an unaligned stack pointer (SP) during execution since it explicitly initializes the SP to 0x2001FFFF (i.e., not 4-byte aligned) in Reset_Handler. This will crash CNC in the real world if the hardware only allows aligned memory accesses. We discovered this bug while diagnosing a crash of ES-Fuzz's DSE. Fuzzware ran well on CNC as QEMU did not complain about the misaligned SP, but its execution traces broke angry DSE. To resolve this, we modified Fuzzware's harness to ensure that CNC keeps a standard-compliant SP during execution.

### 5.3 Development and Runtime Overheads

It takes additional development effort and computational resources at runtime to equip a given firmware fuzzer with ES-Fuzz. The development overhead stems from the required adaptation of the given fuzzing harness to obtain ES-Fuzz's instrumented harness and accommodate ES-Fuzz's MMIO models. We built the first part of our ES-Fuzz implementation in Sec. 4.5 for this purpose with $\sim 1100$ lines of code. We will need to rebuild this part if Fuzzware is replaced by other firmware fuzzers such as Hoedur [23] and MultiFuzz [7]. In contrast, the second part (the program for model
generation) of our implementation is reusable. Note that we do not need to rebuild the first part for different firmware under test.

The runtime overhead refers to ES-Fuzz's CPU and memory usage for generating stateful and adaptable MMIO models, which is in addition to the resource usage of the given firmware fuzzer. To justify this additional resource usage, we compared the code coverage of our ES-Fuzz implementation and vanilla Fuzzware within the same CPU time. We ran these two fuzzers on the 11 firmware highlighted in Fig. 3 with the settings in Sec. 5.1 except that Fuzzware would keep running until it spends as much CPU time as ES-Fuzz. Both ES-Fuzz and Fuzzware generate their MMIO models sporadically, concurrently with firmware fuzzing, and on an indefinite number of cores. So, we measured their CPU time using the CPU accounting option of systemd-run. Table 4 lists the CPU time (in hours) and code coverage of these two fuzzers in the left half. Within the same CPU time, Fuzzware is shown to cover more code in every firmware under test when equipped with ES-Fuzz.

Table 2: Data chunks modeled by ES-Fuzz in different runs

sections.text:
### 5.4 Modeled Data Chunks

We analyzed ES-Fuzz's MMIO models generated in the three trials in Sec. 5.1 to better understand ES-Fuzz's improvement of Fuzzware's coverage shown in Fig. 3. Table 2 lists the data chunks modeled by ES-Fuzz in the firmware under test and the evolving MMIO models of ES-Fuzz for these data chunks. It lists the data chunks and models per firmware in chronological order of ES-Fuzz's model generation. Each firmware's data chunks from different peripherals are separated by solid lines, while ES-Fuzz's models for the same data chunk in different runs are separated by dashed lines.

Each MMIO model in Table 2 describes the firmware's expectations of a data chunk retrieved by multiple MMIO reads. The modeled data chunks range from user commands and lightweight network packets to Ethernet settings and timer values. Moreover, Table 2 shows that per data chunk, ES-Fuzz usually generated MMIO models in later runs that describe the firmware expectations (1) more accurately or (2) in different contexts of data usage. Take GPS Tracker and uTasker MODBUS/USB as examples. Their initial MMIO models respectively describe the peripheral responses during the firmware setup and the commands on the main menu. Their later models describe the headers in the peripheral responses during the firmware routines and the LAN/IO/USB-related commands. Their final models further describe the payload in some such peripheral responses and the arguments of some such commands. The more coverage bottlenecks Fuzzware faced during the trials, the more accurate and versatile ES-Fuzz's MMIO models became and the more they improved Fuzzware's coverage.

We confirmed a few false alarms and misses in ES-Fuzz's MMIO models based on the source code and disassembly of the firmware under test. Those models were thus excluded from Table 2. A false alarm is a model that wrongly describes the firmware expectations of the modeled data chunk. A miss is the absence of a model that we expect ES-Fuzz to have generated for the firmware under test. The confirmed false alarms arose from the mismatches between the modeled MMIO reads and firmware strings. These false alarms did not hurt ES-Fuzz's code coverage in the three trials. The dummy models in Sec. 4.4 provided ES-Fuzz a way out, as discussed in Sec. 5.1. A noteworthy miss we confirmed is that ES-Fuzz did not model the G-codes in 3D Printer. Our ES-Fuzz implementation adopts Fuzzware as the given firmware fuzzer, which tends to get stuck in the startup code of 3D Printer [7, 10, 23]. As a result, ES-Fuzz cannot model any data chunk retrieved by this firmware's application code.

### 5.5 Importance of DSE Heuristics

ES-Fuzz's DSE adopts the heuristics described in Sec. 4.3 to prioritize, prune, or pre-constrain symbolic firmware states and mitigate path explosions. To evaluate these heuristics against path explosions, we ran ES-Fuzz's DSE and a vanilla DSE on the 11 firmware highlighted in Fig. 3. The vanilla DSE is a copy of ES-Fuzz's DSE with the heuristics under evaluation disabled. We set up each DSE on each firmware to re-run the single-core DSE instance that took the median time to reach a wanted BB in ES-Fuzz's trials in Sec. 5.1. Each DSE was configured to terminate upon reaching a wanted BB, abort when consuming $>90 \mathrm{~GB}$ of RAM, and never time out. Thus,
it would either succeed by reaching a wanted BB or fail by running out of memory when running on each firmware. Table 4 shows in the right half each DSE's CPU time, RAM usage (measured by /usr/bin/time -v), and success or failure.

The vanilla DSE failed to reach any wanted BB in 6 of the 11 firmware, even with 90 GB of RAM. In Console and GPS Tracker, it required 87 x and 12 x as much CPU time (plus 56 x and 8 x as much RAM) as ES-Fuzz's DSE to reach a wanted BB. While it outperformed ES-Fuzz's DSE in ChibiOS RTC, Gateway, and uTasker USB, the differences in resource usage were much smaller than in the cases where ES-Fuzz's DSE performed better. The above observations suggest that a vanilla DSE (e.g., used in DevFuzz [26]) is not applicable to the problem ES-Fuzz is addressing.

In summary, ES-Fuzz raised Fuzzware's code coverage by up to $54 \%$ in 11 of the 24 firmware under test and triggered additional bugs in 5 of them without hurting the coverage in others. ES-Fuzz's MMIO models accurately describe a wide range of data chunks that each firmware expects to receive via multiple MMIO reads in different stages of operation. ES-Fuzz and its DSE make better use of computational resources than vanilla Fuzzware and DSE.

## 6 DISCUSSION

There are several directions for improving ES-Fuzz. First, angr may not faithfully emulate the code in the firmware under test during ES-Fuzz's DSE. It ignores the MRS and MSR instructions that access the Interrupt Program Status Register. To ensure that the DSE will comply with the ARM Cortex-M standard, our ES-Fuzz implementation customizes angr's emulation of such instructions at the cost of the DSE speed. We observed more issues when evaluating ES-Fuzz. The DSE took an infeasible branch in the ChibiOS RTC firmware. It stalled upon certain conditional instructions in Robot and Thermostat. We have reported these issues to angr developers.

Second, the test case considered by ES-Fuzz in each run may not prompt the firmware under test to execute enough MMIO reads to retrieve a complete data chunk. Also, this test case may not cover any of the firmware code for processing a data chunk. In theory, ES-Fuzz could filter out such undesired test cases beforehand by running the instrumented harness in Sec. 4.1 with every fuzzergenerated test case. In practice, however, this would require large amounts of CPU time and memory. Developing a resource-efficient alternative is part of our future work.

Third, ES-Fuzz requires the MMIO reads in the same group to have occurred in the same type of IRQ contexts and from the same MMIO register. This prevents each group from having too many reads or heterogeneous reads. The DSE on each group will thus run efficiently without too many symbols. The given firmware fuzzer will thus use each of ES-Fuzz's MMIO models efficiently by considering only a single type of MMIO reads. A drawback of this design is that ES-Fuzz's MMIO models will not capture the correlation between MMIO reads of different types. Some prior works [13, 22, 27] designed their models likewise. [16] modeled some correlated MMIO reads of different types, but this topic, in general, remains an open problem.

Lastly, ES-Fuzz's DSE may not execute an ISR along the path recorded in a given execution trace. Our implementation of ES-Fuzz handles such a situation by tolerating minor deviations from the

recorded path, re-executing the ISR later, or skipping the ISR. Thus, this situation does not hurt ES-Fuzz's performance in practice. It arises due to the difference in time when ES-Fuzz's DSE and the given firmware fuzzer execute an ISR. The DSE runs all the (necessary) ISRs as soon as possible, while the fuzzer runs them periodically. The DSE and the fuzzer may thus run the same ISR along different paths if the ISR's control flow depends on the firmware code executed so far (via a mutex, a full UART buffer, etc.). This implies an open research problem of fuzz-testing ES firmware with different IRQ timings.

## 7 RELATED WORK
### 7.1 Rehosting-based Firmware Fuzzing

Rehosting-based firmware fuzzers test bare-metal ES firmware in a fully emulated environment without hooking up the real firmware peripherals. They emulate the MMIO, IRQ [12, 16, 28], or DMA [20, 28] behavior of firmware peripherals to achieve decent code coverage. Most of them emulate the MMIO behavior with MMIO models. PRETENDER [16] records real-world firmware executions and builds stateful MMIO models that replay the recorded peripheral responses. P2IM [13] classifies each MMIO access in the fuzzed firmware by the surrounding code and models the MMIO access accordingly. $\mu$ Emu [27] runs DSE on each unmodeled MMIO read that occurs during fuzzing to determine the data value retrieved by the read. It will thereafter reuse this data value for the same type of MMIO reads. Both P2IM and $\mu$ Emu avoid modeling the MMIO reads from data registers. $\mu$ Emu may replay constant strings in the fuzzed firmware to handle the initial reads from a data register in each firmware execution. Jetset [17] only models MMIO reads in the startup code of the fuzzed firmware and requires users to specify the DSE destinations. 5Emu [28] automatically extracts MMIO models from peripheral specifications. Fuzzware [22] assigns multi-valued models (still stateless and fixed) to some MMIO reads in the fuzzed firmware. It achieves higher code coverage than the aforementioned works, represents the SOTA in MMIO modeling, and is thus used as the given firmware fuzzer in our ES-Fuzz implementation. ES-Fuzz builds stateful and adaptable models for MMIO reads in the fuzzed firmware that collectively retrieve a data chunk. These models improve the given firmware fuzzer's code and bug coverage, as shown in Sec. 5.

Hoedur [23] and MultiFuzz [7] are SOTA firmware fuzzers that redesign their core fuzzing engines to generate multi-stream firmware inputs. As stated in these papers, their approaches are orthogonal and complementary to MMIO modeling. Hoedur's implementation integrates Fuzzware to enhance the fuzz-testing performance using MMIO models. This indicates that Hoedur and MultiFuzz, if equipped with ES-Fuzz, will likely achieve better code/bug coverage. To achieve this, one must manually revise Hoedur's and MultiFuzz's fuzzing harnesses (just once). SplITS [11] solves a problem similar to Hoedur's and MultiFuzz's but in the specific context of string comparisons during fuzzing.

Recent studies in rehosting-based firmware fuzzing explore beyond MMIO models and multi-stream inputs. Laelaps [5] runs DSE on every MMIO read in firmware executions without caching the DSE results. The DSE spans only a few BBs but significantly slows down firmware executions. Ember-IO [10] handles firmware MMIO
using code instrumentation instead of MMIO models. Icicle [6] is an emulator that provides firmware fuzzers with an interface to ISA-agnostic code instrumentation. SAFIREFUZZ [24] runs CortexM firmware on ARM-based servers to leverage the powerful cores compatible with the firmware ISA.

### 7.2 Stateful Fuzzing of Other Programs

Stateful fuzzing has been applied to programs that are not ES firmware. Ijon [1] leverages human annotations and inspections during fuzzing to explore the deep state space of a program. DevFuzz [26] navigates through the probing logic of a device driver (analogous to the startup code of ES firmware) using a stateful but deterministic peripheral model. To build the model, DevFuzz runs a vanilla DSE on the probing logic and terminates the DSE based on kernel dynamic debugging. Morphuzz [4] identifies the semantic dependencies in a virtual device based on the principles of hypervisor design. ViDeZZo [18] fuzz-tests a virtual device with the knowledge of intra-message dependencies from a human security analyst. The analyst extracts the dependencies from the virtual device's source code and encodes them in ViDeZZo's descriptive grammar. Truman [19] fuzz-tests a virtual device by automatically learning the device's inter-message, intra-message, and state dependencies from the corresponding OS driver. It assumes the driver's use of specific kernel functions and statically analyzes the driver's source code accordingly. Note, however, that these works do not address ES-Fuzz's research problem. They learn the statefulness of a program under test from human annotations, source code, or the program's use of specific OS support. These prerequisites are not available in the common settings of rehosting-based firmware fuzzing and not assumed by recent firmware fuzzers like ES-Fuzz and $[7,13,22,23,27]$.

## 8 CONCLUSION

In this paper, we have proposed ES-Fuzz to build stateful and adaptable MMIO models for rehosting-based firmware fuzzing. ES-Fuzz complements existing approaches by more accurately describing MMIO reads in ES firmware that collectively retrieve a data chunk. Thus, a SOTA fuzzer can cover more code in the firmware under test when equipped with ES-Fuzz. ES-Fuzz runs concurrently with the fuzzer and starts a new run whenever the fuzzer's coverage stops growing. In each run, ES-Fuzz attempts to break the coverage bottleneck with new stateful MMIO models. First, it generates a detailed trace of the firmware under test running with a high-coverage test case. Then, it groups MMIO reads in the trace that have collectively retrieved a data chunk. Lastly, it builds stateful models for each group of MMIO reads using DSE and heuristics. The given fuzzer will use these MMIO models in subsequent firmware fuzzing. We have implemented ES-Fuzz with Fuzzware as the fuzzer and evaluated our implementation with 24 popular ES firmware in prior works. ES-Fuzz is shown to boost Fuzzware's code coverage by up to $54 \%$ in 11 of them, discover new vulnerabilities in 5 of them, and model a wide range of MMIO-retrieved data chunks.

## A FUZZER-SPECIFIC HEURISTICS

ES-Fuzz only models MMIO reads in the firmware under test that collectively retrieve a data chunk. Therefore, the taint analysis in Sec. 4.1 does not taint the data retrieved by certain MMIO reads based on the heuristics specific to the firmware fuzzer in use. If the fuzzer in use is Fuzzware [22], the analysis ignores the reads assigned a Constant (single-valued) or Passthrough (normal-memory) model by the fuzzer. A Constant model is typically assigned to a read that retrieves a peripheral's status or simple data. A Passthrough

model is typically assigned to a read from a control register described in Sec. 2.1. If the fuzzer in use is $\mu$ Emu [27] or P2IM [13], the analysis ignores the reads not from the fuzzer-identified data registers. These reads are likely from a status (SR) or control (CR) register described in Sec. 2.1. A firmware fuzzer can handle them without ES-Fuzz's MMIO models, by assigning SR reads with stateless MMIO models and treating CR reads as normal memory reads (i.e., RAM reads).

## B COMPARISON WITH DEVFUZZ

One may wonder if DevFuzz [26], a recent work on device-driver fuzzing, has solved the research problem addressed by ES-Fuzz. DevFuzz builds part of its MMIO models for driver fuzz-testing using DSE. ES-Fuzz, Fuzzware [22], uEmu [27], and Jetset [17] build MMIO models for firmware fuzz-testing using DSE as well. However, DevFuzz is not applicable to our research problem as its vanilla DSE is prone to path explosions and its generation of MMIO models does not support IRQ handling.

Most existing approaches to building MMIO models for firmware fuzzing customize their DSE to make it feasible. ES-Fuzz, Fuzzware, uEmu, and Jetset are among those approaches. They provide details of the significant effort made on top of a vanilla DSE to mitigate path explosions in their respective system designs (e.g., see Sec. 4.3). The effort includes well-defined DSE scopes, heuristics for prioritizing or pruning symbolic firmware states, specific MMIO reads to symbolize per DSE, etc. We evaluated ES-Fuzz's DSE heuristics in Sec. 5.5 against path explosions and provided the results in the right half of Table 4. The results indicate that a vanilla DSE is unlikely to generate ES-Fuzz's MMIO models before it runs out of memory.

In contrast, DevFuzz does not elaborate on its modifications of a vanilla DSE. It uses DSE to build part of its MMIO models (i.e., the probe models) and encounters path explosions even in this limited use case. Sec. 4.1 of [26] ends with a statement "DevFuzz may not be able to generate a probe model. The reason is that symbolic execution may fail to complete the probing phase if the probing logic is too complex to solve within some time budget, and/or if it requires DMA/IRQ that are rare so DevFuzz's (current) symbolic execution does not support." DevFuzz only mentions its effort to constrain DSE in a paragraph in Sec. 4.1. The effort is a stub script that determines the end of DSE with kernel dynamic debugging. This is far from enough as compared to the recent works on firmware fuzzing. Moreover, a kernel-dependent method does not apply to rehosting-based firmware fuzzing.

Any solution to the problem addressed by ES-Fuzz should not just constrain its DSE carefully but also support IRQ handling when
generating its MMIO models. A large fraction of the MMIO reads modeled by ES-Fuzz occur in ISRs: ESes often receive the data spanning multiple MMIO reads via asynchronous serial communications. The support for IRQ handling is thus essential. ES-Fuzz runs ISRs during the DSE for generating MMIO models (Sec. 4.3.1). DevFuzz [26], as admitted in the above-quoted statement, does not have this feature in its DSE. DevFuzz's target MMIOs rarely occur in an IRQ context, whereas IRQ handling is an important source of ES-Fuzz's target MMIOs. This again shows why DevFuzz cannot apply to the problem ES-Fuzz is addressing.

Some may still argue that DevFuzz builds post-probing MMIO models beside probe models. The post-probing models target the MMIO behavior of a device driver after booting. ES-Fuzz's MMIO models also benefit the testing of the firmware code after booting the most. However, DevFuzz builds its post-probing models with a static value analysis instead of DSE. The analysis runs on the source code of the program under test, which is unavailable for rehosting-based firmware fuzzing. Moreover, the resulting MMIO models do not distinguish the MMIO reads from the same memory and instruction addresses. In contrast, ES-Fuzz is motivated by the need for MMIO models that distinguish such reads.

## C MORE EVALUATION RESULTS

We evaluated ES-Fuzz with 24 ES firmware widely used in prior work [11, 13, 16, 22, 27] by measuring the additional code coverage in them that ES-Fuzz brings to a given firmware fuzzer. Specifically, we tested each firmware with both vanilla Fuzzware and our ES-Fuzz implementation in Sec. 4.5 three times, each time for 24 hours. Then, we compared the code coverage of the two firmware fuzzers in the three trials, as shown in Fig. 3 and Table 3. Fig. 3 plots the coverage growth of ES-Fuzz and Fuzzware over time in the firmware where ES-Fuzz improved Fuzzware's coverage. Table 3 lists the total number of BBs in each firmware and the numbers of those covered by ES-Fuzz and Fuzzware in each trial. The horizontal lines divide Table 3 into three parts. The first part shows the firmware where ES-Fuzz improved Fuzzware's coverage. The second part shows the firmware where ES-Fuzz generated new MMIO models for Fuzzware but did not improve Fuzzware's coverage. The last part shows the firmware where ES-Fuzz did not generate any MMIO models for Fuzzware. We also compared our ES-Fuzz implementation with vanilla Fuzzware and ES-Fuzz's DSE with a vanilla DSE regarding their resource efficiency. The results in Table 4 justify ES-Fuzz's use of (1) additional cores for generating MMIO models and (2) DSE heuristics described in Sec. 4.3.

abstract:
Gray-box fuzzing is widely used for testing embedded systems (ESes).
State-of-the-art (SOTA) gray-box fuzzers test ES firmware in fully emulated
environments without real peripherals. They emulate missing peripherals to
achieve decent code coverage. Some fuzzers infer the memory-mapped I/O (MMIO)
behavior of firmware peripherals from the firmware binary. We find that these
fuzzers emulate the inferred MMIO behavior using stateless and non-adaptive
MMIO models, which perform poorly in handling ES firmware's MMIO reads to
collectively retrieve a data chunk. This leaves ample room for improving the
code coverage of these fuzzers.
  We propose ES-Fuzz to improve the code coverage of each such fuzzer using
stateful MMIO models that adapt to overcome the fuzzer's coverage bottlenecks.
ES-Fuzz runs concurrently with a given fuzzer and starts a new run whenever the
fuzzer's coverage stagnates. In each run, ES-Fuzz leverages a high-coverage
test case to generate new stateful MMIO models that boost the coverage further.
We have implemented ES-Fuzz upon Fuzzware and evaluated it with 24 popular ES
firmware. ES-Fuzz is shown to enhance Fuzzware's coverage by up to 54% in 11 of
them and trigger additional bugs in 5 of them without hurting the coverage in
the remainder. ES-Fuzz's MMIO models are shown to describe a wide range of
MMIO-retrieved data chunks and the firmware's usage of the same data chunk in
various contexts.
